page.title: List of books banned by governments

| ''About a Silence in Literature''<!-- O jednom Äutanju u knjiÅ¾evnosti --> || Å½ivorad StojkoviÄ || Essay || Banned in [[Federal People's Republic of Yugoslavia|Yugoslavia]] by court order in 1951<ref name="Krivicna estetika 32">{{cite news |first=Marinko |last=ArsiÄ Ivkov |authorlink=Marinko ArsiÄ Ivkov |title=KriviÄna estetika (32) |url=http://www.dnevnik.rs/arhiva/23-06-2002/Strane/feljton.htm |work=[[Dnevnik (Novi Sad)|Dnevnik]] |location=[[Novi Sad]] |date=2002-06-23 |accessdate=April 25, 2009 |language=Serbian }}</ref>.
| ''About a Silence in Literature''<!-- O jednom Äutanju u knjiÅ¾evnosti --> || Å½ivorad StojkoviÄ || Essay || Banned in [[Federal People's Republic of Yugoslavia|Yugoslavia]] by court order in 1951<ref name="Krivicna estetika 32">{{cite news |first=Marinko |last=ArsiÄ Ivkov |authorlink=Marinko ArsiÄ Ivkov |title=KriviÄna estetika (32) |url=http://www.dnevnik.rs/arhiva/23-06-2002/Strane/feljton.htm |work=[[Dnevnik (Novi Sad)|Dnevnik]] |location=[[Novi Sad]] |date=2002-06-23 |accessdate=April 25, 2009 |language=Serbian }}</ref>.

| ''A Feast for the Seaweeds''<!-- Walimah li A'ashab al-Bahr --> || [[Haidar Haidar]] || Novel || Banned in Egypt and several other Arab states, and even resulted in a belated angry reaction from the clerics of Al-Azhar University upon reprinting in Egypt in the year 2000. The clerics issued a Fatwa banning the novel, and accused Haidar of heresy and offending Islam. [[Al-Azhar University]] students staged huge protests against the novel, that eventually led to its confiscation.<ref>http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2001/519/cu7.htm</ref><ref>http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/1135908.stm</ref><ref>http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/746766.stm</ref>
+
| ''[[A Feast for the Seaweeds]]''<!-- Walimah li A'ashab al-Bahr --> || [[Haidar Haidar]] || Novel || Banned in Egypt and several other Arab states, and even resulted in a belated angry reaction from the clerics of Al-Azhar University upon reprinting in Egypt in the year 2000. The clerics issued a Fatwa banning the novel, and accused Haidar of heresy and offending Islam. [[Al-Azhar University]] students staged huge protests against the novel, that eventually led to its confiscation.<ref>http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2001/519/cu7.htm</ref><ref>http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/1135908.stm</ref><ref>http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/746766.stm</ref>
|-
|-
| ''[[Alice's Adventures in Wonderland]]'' || [[Lewis Carroll]] || Children's Novel/Adventure || Banned in the province of Hunan, China (1931) for the portrayal of [[anthropomorphism|anthropomorphized]] animals acting on the same level as humans.<ref>[http://www.alice-in-wonderland.net/alice11.html#11]</ref>
| ''[[Alice's Adventures in Wonderland]]'' || [[Lewis Carroll]] || Children's Novel/Adventure || Banned in the province of Hunan, China (1931) for the portrayal of [[anthropomorphism|anthropomorphized]] animals acting on the same level as humans.<ref>[http://www.alice-in-wonderland.net/alice11.html#11]</ref>
